lain," and they resolved 10 fight again eli
the next day. They were, however, put
under arrest, when Col. Fitzgerald had the
audacity to follow Lord kingston's family to
ireland, to obtain the object of his seduction
from her parents. Col. King hearing of
this, repaired to the Inn where Col. Fitz-
gerald put up. Col. Fitzgerald had locked
himself in his room, and refused admission
to Col. King, who broke open the door, and
running to case of pistols, seized one, and
desired Col. f. to take the other. The par
ties now grappled and were fighting when
Lord Kingston entered the room, and per-
ceiving from the position of the parties, that
his son must lose his life, he instantly shot
Col. Fitzgerald dead upon the spot. In
1905, a very singular duel took place in
Hyde Park, between Lieut.. w. of the ma
Wy, and Capt. ]. of the army. Capt. l hal
seduced the Leutenant's sister. Lieutena t
w. seemed impressed with deep sense Of
melancholy. He insisted that the distance
should be six PAGES. At this distance they
fired, and the shot of Capt. l. struck the
guard of Lieut. WIS pistol and tore off two
fingers of his right hand. The Lieut. deib-
erately wrapped his handkerchief round the
wound. and looking solemnly to heaven, ex-
claimed ~ have left hand which never
1aiieu me. Ahey aSalh took khc Brounu
Lieut.. w. looked steadfasty at Capt. and
casting his eyes to heaven, was heard to ut
ter "forgive me-" They fired, and both fell


Capt. I. received the ball in his head. and
died instantly. The Lieutenant was shot
through the breast. He inquired if Cap. l.:
wound was mortal. Being answered in the
affirmative, he thanked heaven he had lived
so long. He then took the mourning ring
off his finger, and said to his second, "Give
this to my sister, and tell her this is the
happiest moment | ever knew" He had
scarcely finished the last word when guam
tity Of blood gushed from his wound, and he
instantly expired.

Wildly and mournfillly the Indian drum
On the deep hush of moonlight forests broke;
Sing us death-song, for thine hour is come
So the red Warriors to their captive spoke.
Still and amidst those dusky forms alone,
A youth, fairhair'd youth, Of England stood,
Like kings son; though from his cheek had


hown


The mantling crimson of the island-blood,
And his press'd lips look'd marble Fiercely


bright,
And high around him, bla2ed the fres of night;
Rocking beneath the cedars to and fro
AS the wind passed, and with afitfu glow
Lighting the victims face:-but who could tell
Of what within his secret heart befel
Known but to Heaven that hour '-Perchance a


thought,
Ofms far home, then so intensely wrought
That its full image, pictured to bis eye
On the dark ground of mortal agony,
Rose clear as dayl-And he might see the band
Of his Young sisters wandering hand in hand
Where the laburnums droopedi OF happy binding
The jasmine, up the doors low pillars winding;
Or, as day faded on their gentle mirth,
Gathering, with braided hair, around the hearth;
Where 81, their mother;-and that mothers face
Its grave sweet smile yet wearing in the place
Where so it ever ilcd!-Perchance the prayer
I.earn'd at her knee came back on his despair;
The blessing from her voice, the very tone
Other 'Gao2,nigh' might breathe from boyhood
he started and looked up:-thck cypress


boughs,


Full of strange sound waved DER him, darkly


red


In the broad stormy fire light; savage brows,
Withtsll plumes crested and wild hues DER


spread,


Girt him like feyersh phantoms; and pale stars
Looked through the branches a, through dun.


geon-bars,


Shedding no hope!--fIe knew, he felt his doom
Oh! what tale to shadow with its gloom
That happy hail in England Idle fear
Would the winds tell t'-who might dream or
They bound him; and that proud young SOL


der strove


His fathers spirit in his breast to wake,
Trusting to die in silence!-He the love
Of many hearts!-the fondly -rcared--the fair,
Gladdening all eyes to see;--And fettered there
He stood beside his death-pyre, and the brand
Flamed M to light it, in the chieftan's hand,
He thought upon his God! Hush hark!-s


cry


Breaks on the stern and dread solennity!
step hath pierced the ring! Who dares intrude
On the dark hunters in their vengefil mood
A Girl-a Young slight girl--a fraan-ke child
OF green savannas and the leafy wild,
Sprnging nnmark'd till then, as some lone flow-


er,


Happy because the sunshine is its dover;
Yet none that knew how early tears are shed,
For hers had mourn'd playmate brother dead.
She had sat gazing on the victim long,
Until the pity of her soul grew strong;
And by its passions deepest foreyer swayed,
Fen to the stake she rushed, and gently laid
His bright head on her bosom, and around
Ills form her slender arms to shield it wound
Like close Lannes; then raised her glittering


eye,


And clear-toned voice that said--tIe shall no


de!'


He shall not dien-the gloomy feres.s thrilled
To that sweet sound. A sudden wonder fel
On the fierce throng, and heart and hand wer


stilled--


Struck down as by the whisper ola spell
They gazed---their dark souls how'd before TIL


maid,


She ofthe dancing step in wood and glade!
And as her cheek flushed through its olive hue
As her black tresses to the night wind few,
Something o'ermastcred them from that youn


mien-


Something of Heaven in silence felt and seem
And seeming to their child like faith token
That the Great Spirit by her voice had spoker
They loosed the bonds that held their captive


breath;


From his pale lips they took the cup of deaths
They quenched the brand beneath the cypre'


tree


fAway" they cried, Young stranger thou art free

''In making the sword blades, there are sever,

Others prefer to make them CT one plate Of steel,

On the 9th OF December. the son of a far
mer called Valentine. was tried at Dijon, in
France, for the murder of young female,
whom he had seduced, of the name of Anne
Eyrard. His family, in order to screen him,
circulated a report that The crime had been
committed by superanuated woman in
state of idiocy; known, however, to be mild
and harmless. This poor creature having
heard the report, and. on the next Sunday,
at the termination of the church service,
observing Valentine in the church yard
near the spot where the unfortunate girl
was buried, suddenly threw herself upon the
grave and cried ort--"Anne Eyrard. come
forth from thy tomb, and say which killed
you--Valentin or T." The strong emotion
which the murderer exhibited when he heard
this extraordinary invocation, was one Of the
circumstances which induced the jury to
convict him.

The commerce of Calcutta as stated in
the French papers, amounts on an average
to fourteen millions of pounds sterling per
year. About six hundred vessels enter that
port annually. In l717, Calcutta was no
thing but an inconslderablc little village
surroundedby marshes and forests: 1t now
contains more than one hundred thousand
houses, and extends more than two Leagues
along the banks of the river. The EnghSa
are estimated at six hundred thousand; ana
the whole population of the city and snSl' W,
rons, within the compass of seventy mlle'
each way,is stated to be more than two NIL
lions.

full articles.article:
better OF, we'll take It ava tie day. Not q.
cross the bridge then, said L. AYE, tho said
the man. was struck with his boldness, but
being sure OF my out look-Come, said !, I'll
bet you bowl of the best ofit in toddy, that you
don't' 'Done,' said the smuggler, and we sep
arated for the present hung on for afew hours
about the bridge ON which took my seat.
had 10. been long there, when few decent
looking men made their appearance, bearing on
their shoulders coffin, covered with a tartan
plaid, as is common with the poorer class in
Scotland. They passed by, closely, ard appear
ed to take the road for Aberdeen. turned my
eyes to the other end of the bride, in expectation
ofbeholdng more cheering prospcct.-ln a
bout an hour, some person tapped ne on the
shoulder; looking around, found it was my
smuggler, wearing a smile upon his features.
Come AVA said he, pay your wager; it is a
caul day, and it viii do very well' How. where,
replied i, you have not wonit' you didna see
the chiefs WI the box plaid, then gaen across
the BRIDGE The truth flashed on my mind;
'And they did carry the dead' ma, ma, said
my friend, they certainly had q dead weight, but
it was three ankcrs o. good Genlivet whiskey'
and he soon gave me such evidence as satisfied
me that he had safely lodged his smugglc.

lain," and they resolved 10 fight again eli
the next day. They were, however, put
under arrest, when Col. Fitzgerald had the
audacity to follow Lord kingston's family to
ireland, to obtain the object of his seduction
from her parents. Col. King hearing of
this, repaired to the Inn where Col. Fitz-
gerald put up. Col. Fitzgerald had locked
himself in his room, and refused admission
to Col. King, who broke open the door, and
running to case of pistols, seized one, and
desired Col. f. to take the other. The par
ties now grappled and were fighting when
Lord Kingston entered the room, and per-
ceiving from the position of the parties, that
his son must lose his life, he instantly shot
Col. Fitzgerald dead upon the spot. In
1905, a very singular duel took place in
Hyde Park, between Lieut.. w. of the ma
Wy, and Capt. ]. of the army. Capt. l hal
seduced the Leutenant's sister. Lieutena t
w. seemed impressed with deep sense Of
melancholy. He insisted that the distance
should be six PAGES. At this distance they
fired, and the shot of Capt. l. struck the
guard of Lieut. WIS pistol and tore off two
fingers of his right hand. The Lieut. deib-
erately wrapped his handkerchief round the
wound. and looking solemnly to heaven, ex-
claimed ~ have left hand which never
1aiieu me. Ahey aSalh took khc Brounu
Lieut.. w. looked steadfasty at Capt. and
casting his eyes to heaven, was heard to ut
ter "forgive me-" They fired, and both fell


Capt. I. received the ball in his head. and
died instantly. The Lieutenant was shot
through the breast. He inquired if Cap. l.:
wound was mortal. Being answered in the
affirmative, he thanked heaven he had lived
so long. He then took the mourning ring
off his finger, and said to his second, "Give
this to my sister, and tell her this is the
happiest moment | ever knew" He had
scarcely finished the last word when guam
tity Of blood gushed from his wound, and he
instantly expired.

full articles.headline:
LAWS OF TIE UNION.

PASSED AT THE SECOND SESSION OF


TIE NINETEENTH CONGRESS-.
full articles.article:
fPUBLIC--NO. s.
AN ACT making appropriation the payment Of
the Revolutlonar, and other Pensions ithc
United States


Belt enacted bu tie Senate and UoHSr #
Representatives. offhe Unned Stairs of Il,
merica IN Congress .4Ssemblcd, That the
following sums be and they arc hereby, re
spectively appropriated towards the militia
~ service of the year one thousand eight
hundred and twenty-seveD, and for Tie Oh
jects following, that is to say:
For the pensions to the Revolutionary pen
soners Of the United States, ono million two
hundred and sixty thousand one hundred
and eighty-fye dollars;
For the invalid and half pay pensioners,
three hundred and one thousand and fifty
five dollars;


For pensions TO the widows and orphans,
twelve Thousand dollars.
| SEC. 2. ind be ii farther enactcd, That
the said sums, respectively. shall be paid
out of any money in the Treasury, not o.
therwise appropriated.


JOHN w. TAYLOR,
i Speaker of the House of Representatives


NATfIA'L MACON,
/ President of the Senate, pro tenn.
Approved: Jan %, 1927.


JOHN QUINCY ADAMS

full articles.headline: fPunIIc-No. III
full articles.article:
AN ACT to allow the citizens Of the Territory
of Michigan to elect the members Of their Lc
gislative council, and for other purposes.


Be it enacted 6y he Senate and Wouse
Of fRetresentatipes IF M- UnHrd MQfeS Of
.4merica in Congress asSemitcd, That
at the next, and at the succeeding election
of members of the Legislative Council Of the
Territory of Michigan. the qualified electors
OF the said Territory may. instead of choosing
26, as heretofore directed. elect IS fit per-
sons as their representatives, in the manner
and with the qualifications no W or hereafter to
be prescribed, by law: which said Reprcscn-
tatives. so-lected. shall be, and constitute,
the said Legislative Council And for the
purpose Of securing an equal representation,
the Governor and Legislative Council OF
said Territory, are hereby authorized and
required to apportion the Representatives
so to he elected as aforesaid. among the sew
eral counties or districts, in the said Terri
tory, in proportion, as near as may be, to the
whole number of inhabitants in each county
or district, exclusive of Indians not taxrd
SEC. 2. fnd be IL further cnscfeG. Tha,
the said Governor and Legislative Council
be, and they are hereby. authorized to pro-
vide bv law for holding, annually, one OF
nOTc AOuTtS, Wv OHt tf lIDuC vi llt JHNlEtN
ofthe Supreme Court Of the said Territory
in each of the counties IN TINT part of the
Territory eastward of the Lake Michigan
and also for the appointment Ola Cl'rk il
each county, TO act as Clerk to the said
Court therein; and further to prescribe the
jurisdiction Of the said Courts, and the pow.
crs aud duties Of the Judge or Judges hold.
ing the same.


SEC. 8. And be II fUwher rnactcd, Tha
the Jndges Of the Supreme Court Of the Ter
ritorv of Michigan have, and my exercise
the right of appointing the Clerk Of the sale
Court, and Of removing him at pleasure.


SEC. 4. ind be Il further enacted, Tha
no member of the Legislative Council shal
be eligible to any Office created. or the fee
of which we're regulated, by law or law
passed while he was member, during tn,
period for which he was elected, and for on,
year thereafter


SEC. S. .dnd be il fWrther enacted. Tha
all laws. and parts of laws, in So far as TIL
same shall be inconsistent with the provs
ions of this act, are hereby repealed; an
further, that Congress have the right, at a
ny time, to alter or repeal this act.
{ JOHN w. TAYLOR,


Speaker OF the House of Representative


NATH'L MACON,


President Of the Senate, pro ten.
. | Approved--Jan. 80 1927.


JOHN QUINCY ADAMS.

full articles.article:
AN ACT to provide for the location of the two


townships Of Land reserved for Seminary of


Learning in the territory of Florida, and to


complete the location Of the grant to the Deaf


and Dumb Asylum of Kentucky


Re il enacted bv the Senate and House Of
Retresentatives ofthe UaHed Stairs IF H.
ncriea in Congress assembled, That the
townships of land reserved in the district OF
East Florida, by all act of Congress. approx
ed the third day of March, one thousand eight
hundred and twenty three, for Seminary Of
Learning, shall be located east of the Appa.
lachicola river, and may be located in Sec
tons corresponding with any of the legal di-
visions into which the public lands are AL

thoriscd to be surveyed so as not to inter-
ferc with private land claims. or the r'gnts
of pre- -em pton; so as not to interfere Win
private land claims; and the township iocat-
cd west of Appalachicola river. as directed


in the aforesaid act, so far as 1t is covered ey
the claims of those entitled to the rights OF
pre- .emption, bv the act approved the TWEEN
" second of April. one thousand eight nun
dred and twenty six, shall be located in sec
tions upon any unappropriated lands IN salo


district of country, until the amount taken
,y said interfcrences shall be satisfied and
discharged.


SEC. Q. .fndbe ii further enaetrd, That
the Governor and Legislative Council OF sald
Territory shall have power to take posses


sion of the lands granted for the use OF
Schools and for Seminary of Learning, and
to lease the same from year to year; and the


money arising from the rent of said lands


shall be appropriated to the use of schools,


and the erection Of Seminary of Learning,
in such manner as they may direct; and they
shall have power TO pass laws Tor the pres


ervation of said lands from intrusion and


trespass until Florida shall be admitted into


the Union as a State.


SEC. s. .dnd be il further enacted. That


the incorporated Deaf and Dumb Asylum


of Kentucky shall have the power, under the
under the direction OF the Secretary OF the
Treasury, of locating SO much OF the town
! shil, of land granted to the SAID institution,


as has been taken by the claims OF those
who are entitled tothe right of pre- e-enption
in the Territory of Florida, under the pro


visions of the act aforesaid; which shall be


locate in sections upon any unaprraoriatcd


and unrescrvetl lands in either of the Terri-


tories of Florida or Arkansas; which said
tracts, when so located, shall be disposed oi


by the corporation Of said Deaf and Dumb
Asylum, agreeably 70 the provisions of an


act passed the fifth OF April, one thousand
eight hundred and twenty six, entitled "an


act fnr the benefit OF the Incorporated Deal


and Dumb Asylum of Kentucky"


AnnroN ed Ian. %, 1927

full articles.headline: SMUGGLING.
full articles.article:
As proof of the extraordinary plan adopted
by the Scotch smugglers to bring their whiskey
in, a certain excise officer, stationed in the neigh
borhood of Aberdeen. relates in the Aberdeen
Journal, the following story


Having notice that quantity of Illicit spirits.
was lodged about the bridge of Dee, fset out tc
watch, as was given TO understand that it would
be removed that night-Calling at house there,
encountered well known smuggler.-'Well
said I, you are not here for nothing-what have
you got' "A smuggle,' said he, but YEN be nae

Florida, was, as amended, ordered to third
reading The Senate was engaged abou,


two hours in Executive business.

olution offered by Mr.. Woods, and discussed

nittce On Reads and Canals TO authorize tho

O''io Canal COMPANY, 70 the amount of twt
!, and half millions. The House in Commit.
. tee OF the Whole on the state of the Uniot


discussed the manufacturers bill. Mr.
, Pierce delivered his sentiments in favor OF i
and Mr.. Claiborne, and Mr.. Mitchell, o
, South Carolina, against il. On motion o
| Mr. Davis Of Massachusetts, the Committed
. then rose.


I the Senate on Wednesday, MIR. Chand


ler from the Committee OH the Militia, re


ported bin to provide for the national de
defence, by the establishment Of an uniform

and for the discipline thereof. The bill fo

= Of Maine was ordered to third reading

Il the sum of two millions of dollars, hithert

= the debt due to the Commissioners of tn
. Sinking Fund, until that debts shall be extin
. guished, was taken up, and after some dis
cussion, was laid on the table.


:. The consideration of the Bankrupt B
y " was resumed Mr.. Smith, of South Care
!. lima, opposed the bill. He was replied to b
4 Mr.. Berrien Mr. Eayne closed the debat
with brief and eloquent speech in supper
of the bill. The question WAS then tax cr


on ordering the bin to thiyI ,eading, an
: decided in the negative.


. III the House of Representatives, acted Q


the Manufacturers Bill in the Committee


the whole on the state of the Union. TIL


proposition of Mr.. Barney, which went


establish fourth minimum was agreed t


Some other propositions were made to


mend, but they were rejected, and the Con
vo cittec then rose and reported the bill. NJ
ol ol Cambreleng moved his amendment in Il
10 House, and commenced some Observation
al in reply to MIR. Davis. who spoke at lengt


and with much ability in favor Of the bill
Of but the House adjourned before Mr.. C.. h;
H. made much progress. 1t is probable that Il
he bill will be to-day ordered to be cngross
of and read a third time.


w. In the Senate on Thursday, the bill f
hit distributing portion of the revenne of t
Of United States among the several States W
"a. called up by Mr.. Dickerson, who explain
&C. its object in a speech of great length on m
IL ton of Mr.. Benton, the bill was then laid

rupt Bill to third reading; which motion,
after a long discussion, was decided in the
affirmative.


The bill was then, on motion Of MIR. San
ford recommitted to select Committee,
with instructions to strike out the ninety
third section.


Messrs. Hayne, Berrien, Sanford, Van

The bill to construct road from point
opposite Memphis, in Tennessee, TO Little
Rock i'll Arkansas, was takenu Mr.. Hen

isiana. After some discussion, the bill, as

The bill for reducing the duty on imported
salt was read second time.


Mr.. Smith, Of Md. supported the bill, and

tion was taken on ordering it to third read
ing, the Senate adjourned.


In the House of Representatives, the
House were again engaged in discussion on

commit the bill. with instructions, was offer
ed by Mr.. Cook, and negatived by vote of
95 to 95.


Mr.. Saunders called up resolution which

of the United States have been authorized
to be printed. In his remarks on the sub
ject he made distinct charge against Mr..
Clay of using the power Of selecting the pa

erencc to the promotion OF his own private
and political view.

tition.


The Senate then adjourned over to Mon


dav.


In the House of Representatives the con


sidcration of the resolution offered by Mr.


Saunders, calling for a return Of the papers


in which the Laws Of United States have


been authorized to be printed, was resum-


ed, the debate on which continued till the
time prescribed for the consideration of res
f olutons had elapsed. TheiIouse was en-.

: bills of q private nature.


The Senate did not sit on Saturday.
In the House of Representatives, the dis

was continued until the expiration OF tn,


hour allowed for that purpose, when Mr.
1 i1amhton, VINO mao Just CDld'neu lne HODr
made an unsuccessful morton to suspend tn,
1 rule. The only speakers on Saturday, were

ofthe Secretary of the United States, ant


Mr.. Wood. who in a few words deprecated
, the protraction of the discussion on resolu
| t on which inquired into motives which ar,


altogether out of the cognisance osthe Hous,
r aud which could lead to no subseq quent pre-
! creding. The residue of the day was devot
+, ed to private bills.


Monda8. FrG, Sin the Senate, the bill
d Tor reducing the duty on imported salt wa
read SECOND time; and after some debate
T was passed ayes "a, noes 81. A messag,
f was received from the President Of the Il
f States transmitting "A letter from the Agen
OF the United States with the Greek Indians


relative to the rights and TERRITORY secured


to that nj zion by the treaty of the 22d Apri
= last After some conversation as to th
= proper Committee to which the subjec
n ought to be referred, the message and tn

If Harrison.


o In the House of Representatives, the res
o oluton offered by Mr.. Saunders, was sup
c ported BY Mr. Hamilton, in speech whcj

full articles.headline: THE AMERICAN FOREST GIRL.
full articles.article:
ny Mrs HeHdnS.
Wildly and mournfillly the Indian drum
On the deep hush of moonlight forests broke;
Sing us death-song, for thine hour is come
So the red Warriors to their captive spoke.
Still and amidst those dusky forms alone,
A youth, fairhair'd youth, Of England stood,
Like kings son; though from his cheek had


hown


The mantling crimson of the island-blood,
And his press'd lips look'd marble Fiercely


bright,
And high around him, bla2ed the fres of night;
Rocking beneath the cedars to and fro
AS the wind passed, and with afitfu glow
Lighting the victims face:-but who could tell
Of what within his secret heart befel
Known but to Heaven that hour '-Perchance a


thought,
Ofms far home, then so intensely wrought
That its full image, pictured to bis eye
On the dark ground of mortal agony,
Rose clear as dayl-And he might see the band
Of his Young sisters wandering hand in hand
Where the laburnums droopedi OF happy binding
The jasmine, up the doors low pillars winding;
Or, as day faded on their gentle mirth,
Gathering, with braided hair, around the hearth;
Where 81, their mother;-and that mothers face
Its grave sweet smile yet wearing in the place
Where so it ever ilcd!-Perchance the prayer
I.earn'd at her knee came back on his despair;
The blessing from her voice, the very tone
Other 'Gao2,nigh' might breathe from boyhood
he started and looked up:-thck cypress


boughs,


Full of strange sound waved DER him, darkly


red


In the broad stormy fire light; savage brows,
Withtsll plumes crested and wild hues DER


spread,


Girt him like feyersh phantoms; and pale stars
Looked through the branches a, through dun.


geon-bars,


Shedding no hope!--fIe knew, he felt his doom
Oh! what tale to shadow with its gloom
That happy hail in England Idle fear
Would the winds tell t'-who might dream or
They bound him; and that proud young SOL


der strove


His fathers spirit in his breast to wake,
Trusting to die in silence!-He the love
Of many hearts!-the fondly -rcared--the fair,
Gladdening all eyes to see;--And fettered there
He stood beside his death-pyre, and the brand
Flamed M to light it, in the chieftan's hand,
He thought upon his God! Hush hark!-s


cry


Breaks on the stern and dread solennity!
step hath pierced the ring! Who dares intrude
On the dark hunters in their vengefil mood
A Girl-a Young slight girl--a fraan-ke child
OF green savannas and the leafy wild,
Sprnging nnmark'd till then, as some lone flow-


er,


Happy because the sunshine is its dover;
Yet none that knew how early tears are shed,

On the 9th OF December. the son of a far
mer called Valentine. was tried at Dijon, in
France, for the murder of young female,
whom he had seduced, of the name of Anne
Eyrard. His family, in order to screen him,
circulated a report that The crime had been
committed by superanuated woman in
state of idiocy; known, however, to be mild
and harmless. This poor creature having
heard the report, and. on the next Sunday,
at the termination of the church service,
observing Valentine in the church yard
near the spot where the unfortunate girl
was buried, suddenly threw herself upon the
grave and cried ort--"Anne Eyrard. come
forth from thy tomb, and say which killed
you--Valentin or T." The strong emotion
which the murderer exhibited when he heard
this extraordinary invocation, was one Of the
circumstances which induced the jury to
convict him.

The commerce of Calcutta as stated in
the French papers, amounts on an average
to fourteen millions of pounds sterling per
year. About six hundred vessels enter that
port annually. In l717, Calcutta was no
thing but an inconslderablc little village
surroundedby marshes and forests: 1t now
contains more than one hundred thousand
houses, and extends more than two Leagues
along the banks of the river. The EnghSa
are estimated at six hundred thousand; ana
the whole population of the city and snSl' W,
rons, within the compass of seventy mlle'
each way,is stated to be more than two NIL
lions.
